The Family Court counsellors have been selected after a rigorous selection process and then have an extensive in-house training program. We are entitled to ask: will that sort of training and selection process be applied in respect of the non-government organisations? 
Also, in resolving family law disputes, it is naïve to assume that some knowledge of family law is not required and, indeed, some knowledge of the likely outcome of proceedings. How can you attempt to resolve a residence or an access matter between a couple when you are not familiar with the likely outcome of that matter, should the people involved go to court? More often than not, these matters are resolved when someone who is properly informed and has the respect of the litigants is able to say, `You have to be sensible here. No-one likes the outcome of the Family Court process because, by definition, you walk away with less than the combined assets you had as a husband and wife; indeed, you walk away, more distressingly than that, with less time with your children because of the different orders made about residence and access to your children.' By its very definition, the Family Court process ends up with people who are dissatisfied because they have less than they started off with, having regard to the nature of the breakdown in the relationship.
What has been vitally important has been the ability of counsellors to say, `I know you're not happy about this and you don't want to see that happen, but if you go on to litigation, this is going to be a likely outcome.' The counsellors with these non-government organisations who have not had that sort of experience are going to be at an extreme disadvantage—or, more specifically, people using that counselling service are going to be at an extreme disadvantage in terms of receiving any meaningful guidance from the counsellor. There are also issues as to who will be available to assist the non-government organisations to reduce any agreement to a written form should they be able to succeed in bringing the parties to an agreement. There are also issues relating to a support network for these counsellors in the non-government organisations. 
The Family Court counsellors, as you would expect, have developed an extensive support network in respect of the quite intense and personal problems that they confront. They are able to consult with their colleagues as to ideas that have been tried and proven to be successful in the experience of these other counsellors. But this is going to be an entirely new territory for these non-government organisations, which will not be able to tap into such a network of support.
One of the vital roles played by Family Court counsellors is the provision of family reports to judges. Judges rely extremely heavily on those family reports because they are getting input presumably from someone they respect who has had the time to spend with the respective parties to the marriage break-up and, more importantly, with their children. Do we lose that important area of input into the Family Court process because of the contracting out of these counselling services? It is very much penny-wise and pound-foolish to look at saving money in the area of counselling. The Attorney himself recognised, when he commented on the Family Court of Australia's annual report for 1999-2000 as recently as 27 October 2000, that:
The use of primary dispute resolution processes resulted in only 6.5 per cent of all matters filed with the court being finalised by judgment during 1999-2000.
That is an outstanding result from these primary dispute resolution processes. Only 93.5 per cent of cases went to trial because of the success of these settlement processes. The proof of the pie is in the eating. These counselling services have had dramatic success in resolving matters without going to litigation. So to diminish the resources available to them and their opportunity to assist parties to come to a resolution outside the judicial process is, as I say, penny-wise and pound-foolish simply because it is more than likely that you will end up with more court hours and paying for the cost of judicial time, an associate, a court reporter, a court officer and even the rental space of those courts. So it is just foolish.
In addition, there will inevitably be additional expenses to the community. The longer that family disputes go on unresolved, the greater the need will be, for instance, for a whole range of additional social services to cope with children who, more often than not, are the ones who suffer trauma in situations of marriage break-up where there is hostility. Indeed, in worst case scenarios, there will also be the need for the intervention of police services if there is a build-up in aggression to the point where domestic violence ensues. Again, we are all familiar with such situations. It is fair to say that those comments are not sensationalist because we are well and truly aware of the need for police to come out in domestic violence situations. The police themselves regard that as one of the most dangerous activities that they confront. But all the time that matters are not resolved, the victims are very much the children. So this disjunction that is creating this artificial division between the Federal Magistrates Service and the Family Court, with the accompanying diminution of resources to the Family Court, has already had significant effects, particularly in rural and regional Australia. 
I was particularly encouraged by my discussion with the Rockhampton practitioners, all of whom appreciated the value of these counselling services, despite the fact that the lawyers did not play a part in attending those counselling proceedings and were cut out of the action from a financial point of view. They all recognised that it was in the interests of their client to achieve a conciliated outcome through an effective counselling process, rather than for the matter to be resolved by litigation. 
It was put to me—and I have to say that I agree with it—that the mere fact a litigation is commenced invariably results in the inability for that matter to settle. As soon as you are required to put down in affidavit form the various accusations and imputations against the other party, particularly in the context of residence and access to children, you automatically inflame the situation so that it takes months to resolve. They put to me the vital importance of counselling at an early date—a suggestion that we will take on board in our policy development, and one that the government may take on board. It was put to me that, other than in matters of urgency of domestic violence or perhaps an abduction, it may well be of benefit to require parties, before they commence proceedings in the Family Court, to file a certificate of attempted resolution through an alternative dispute resolution mechanism, where it is not necessary to up the ante by setting out in writing the various accusations, airing the dirty laundry and aggravating both parties. That is certainly something to bear in mind. I make those points not as an aside but to say how directly important counselling services are in this area.
We are having a situation where, because of the depletion of the resources of the Family Court, those counselling services are being contracted out in circumstances where I do not believe that contracting out is going to deliver services effectively. At the same time—and this is a vitally important point—it does not appear that the Federal Magistrates Service has the resources to tap into these counselling services. I might add that the ridiculous situation is now occurring in Rockhampton where, after losing their staff member of the registry because of the reduction of registry hours, there are apparently negotiations occurring as to whether the Federal Magistrates Service will place some additional demand on the registry such that it could be at least partially reopened during those non-sitting periods.
You have had a reduction or sucking out of assets result in reduced services for the community. Perhaps commonsense is prevailing so the wave is starting to come in a bit in terms of people resolving these practical differences that exist between the way in which the Federal Magistrates Service and the Family Court conduct themselves. 
That is very relevant in terms of the way circuits are conducted. If you lose 10 per cent of your operating budget the inevitable consequence for the Family Court is that they are going to have to reduce the amount of circuit time they undertake—and circuits are vitally important to the delivery of justice to rural and regional Australia. To what extent will the Federal Magistrates Service be able to fill that void? They already have intense demands in the capital cities for their services. The Chief Federal Magistrate has indicated that she herself has some resourcing questions if their workload increases, as one would expect it will. That has to put into question the extent to which the Federal Magistrates Service will be able to undertake circuit work. What is going to be the mechanism for coordinating circuits undertaken by the Federal Magistrates Service as opposed to the circuit work undertaken by the Family Court? They are vitally important questions because, for a start, when is the Rockhampton registry going to be open? Is it only going to be open during the circuit weeks of the Family Court or will it be open separately or in addition during the circuit weeks of the Federal Magistrates Service? This is a vitally important question not only for the registry staff but also for people wishing to use the registry. 
Put yourself in the position, as it was explained to me, of these practitioners. What body, what court, do they commence the proceedings in? Do they commence the proceedings in the Family Court, where they know there is going to be at least some access to counselling, albeit, it now appears, through the contracting out arrangement? Or do they commence it with the Federal Magistrates Service, where it was conceded that, because of the fewer matters in that service, they will get a more expedited hearing date, but they will not have the opportunity for the counselling services that are available? Again, what court they commence it in will depend very much on the extent to which circuits will be undertaken by the Federal Magistrates Service. These sorts of things just have not been worked through. It is already having an effect on rural and regional Australia. It is certainly having an effect on the administration of justice. 
This is frustrating because there were alternatives. We argued, and it indeed is still our position, that it would have been preferable to include what we acknowledge as a required magistrates level of justice within the existing Family Court and Federal Court structures. A good example is how the Western Australian Family Court operates, where, yes, there is a magistrates service incorporated within that court but it very much operates as the one unit, where magistrates and judges alike work off the one docket system so matters flow freely between them, depending on the level of complexity, urgency and the like. Incorporation of the Magistrates Service within the existing family and federal courts would have avoided these unnecessary, practical problems that I have referred to—problems because of the artificial and unnecessary division between the jurisdictions, particularly in the Family Court area.
Another alternative, or an additional avenue that would have been available, was proposed by three state Attorneys-General. Jan Wade in Victoria, Matt Foley in Queensland and Jeff Shaw in New South Wales all said, `Why are you creating this additional service? We have magistrates all through our states in regional and rural areas. Why don't we look at sitting down with an agreement for dual commissions to appropriately trained magistrates'—they concede that not all magistrates would have the training—`so that we could literally get these sorts of services out into the bush?' That was totally ignored by the government. Again, one has to question the merits of this ridiculous step of spending some $27 million to establish an entirely separate court, which has caused fractures and unnecessary divisions in the delivery of justice. As a New South Wales Law Society Journal concluded:
From the Federal government's perspective, however, the best use of the $27 million will be the disappearance of the Family Court from television current affairs programs and the front pages of the press.
One suspects that that is the motive of the government, but it is not sufficient for the administration of justice. (Time expired).
Debate (on motion by Ms Worth) adjourned.

name: Macklin, Jenny, MP
text:
—Madam Deputy Speaker, before I begin my remarks on the National Health Amendment (Improved Monitoring of Entitlements to Pharmaceutical Benefits) Bill 2000, I am sure you would not mind, and nor would the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, who is at the table, if I made a few remarks about White Wreath Day. A large number of us have been out on the lawns of Parliament House, where a very powerful statement has been made by the wreaths laid out on the lawns commemorating all the people who have died from suicide this year. I would like to say, on behalf of the whole parliament, how much we owe Fanita Clark, the woman who has organised White Wreath Day, for bringing this very powerful statement to the parliament.
One of the most important things, as she said in her remarks out on the lawns, is, of course, to bring mental illness and suicide out into the open so that it is talked about in our community and not hidden or treated as something that cannot be addressed. I wanted to take a moment before beginning my remarks on this bill to pay tribute to her work. She suffered the tragedy of losing her own son to suicide. All of us have a little more understanding of the pain that she has gone through, given our terrible loss here in the parliament with Greg Wilton's suicide. I recommend to all members that they go out and spend a bit of time looking at the stories that are displayed out on the lawns. Hopefully, as a result, we will all take much more action to talk about the issues and also to improve our policies with respect to mental illness.
The aim of this bill is to tighten the process for determining eligibility for the $3.8 billion Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. As all of us know, the PBS, as we call it, is a very successful Commonwealth program that provides the community with reliable and affordable access to necessary and cost-effective medicines. Under the scheme the Commonwealth pays about 82 per cent of the cost of PBS listed drugs. Pensioners, of course, are required to pay only $3.30 for each prescription, which makes sure that they have access to the medicines that they need at an affordable price.
It is a very significant program. As at 1 February last year, the scheme covered an enormous amount of medicines—559 different medicines—while 140 million prescriptions are supplied each year under the PBS. It is very important that the entitlement arrangements are properly administered so that we can ensure that only eligible people are receiving benefits. Eligibility for the scheme is restricted to Australian residents and to visitors from countries with which Australia has a reciprocal health care agreement. These countries are the UK, Ireland, New Zealand, Malta, Italy, Sweden, the Netherlands and Finland.
Under the bill, the government wants to make it harder for ineligible people, such as tourists, overseas visitors and people with non-resident status, to obtain subsidised drugs. The amendments also attempt to reduce the incidence of doctor shopping. Doctor shopping, as I am sure most people are aware, involves consumers obtaining large quantities of subsidised drugs for recreational drug use, sale for profit or to send to friends overseas by presenting prescriptions from different doctors to different pharmacists for the same drug. 
The opposition, of course, supports both of these goals. We want to make sure that the PBS works effectively and cuts down on fraud. However, we want to make sure that, in meeting that objective, we do not do so at the expense of privacy. We have just had a very long debate in the parliament between the Attorney-General and the shadow Attorney-General in trying to improve the government's privacy legislation. One of the critical areas in that regard is in the area of privacy over an individual's health information. We certainly have some concerns, not so much about what this bill is trying to do but about where the government is heading with unique patient identifiers and the lack of privacy protection for people's individual health information. 
The other area that needs a very high priority when it comes to pharmaceuticals is making sure that safety and quality are at the top of the agenda. At the moment the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme works in such a way that people do not have to prove their eligibility. Concessional patients such as pensioners must produce a health card, but no proof of eligibility is currently required for the general benefit which all of us are entitled to. It therefore has been difficult for pharmacists to determine the entitlement status of the customer or to recognise `doctor shoppers'. The desirability of tightening the legislative requirements to make sure that pharmacists can check a customer's eligibility is therefore recognised, but it must be ensured that we are doing it in a cost-effective way. I am not sure that this bill really achieves that.
The bill will require doctors and other prescribers to put the patient's Medicare number on each prescription. It will allow pharmacists to check who is eligible for the PBS and will assist the Health Insurance Commission and pharmacists to identify doctor shoppers. When fully implemented, the government will not pay pharmacists unless they have checked the person's Medicare number and the expiry date before dispensing medicines. In addition, if the number is incorrect when compared with the Health Insurance Commission data, pharmacists will be required to actually track down the customer in order to correct their Medicare number or to obtain the balance of the payment for the pharmaceuticals. The bill permits pharmacists and doctors to keep the Medicare numbers for future use for the same patients but requires them to maintain the privacy of this information. The bill creates various offences for disclosing or misusing Medicare numbers. To that degree, privacy of the Medicare number certainly is protected.
There are various aspects of the scheme, though, that we have had representations about and that do need more careful thought and design. A key concern has been the speed with which the government proposes to implement the arrangements. There are three stages, leading to July 2001, through which implementation is going to proceed. Initially, pharmacists are going to get a discretionary power to request a Medicare number from a person presenting a prescription and, with that person's consent, will be allowed to store that number. This phase will only operate for a few weeks because, unfortunately, it has taken the government a very long time to get this legislation into the parliament for debate.
From 1 January next year—not very long away—the pharmacist must ask for the Medicare number. If the number is not provided, the person will not be eligible to receive the pharmaceutical benefit and will have to pay the full price. Some people who do not carry around their Medicare card might get a rude shock, particularly if they are down at the beach during the summer holidays and need to fill a prescription. The third phase starts on 3 July next year, when the provision of a Medicare number will become mandatory both for the doctor and for the pharmacist. There are provisions allowing the correction of Medicare numbers during the phase-in, but after that the rules become quite strict.
The larger concern, though, has been that this bill is simply the beginning, the thin edge of the wedge, of what has been foreshadowed by the government in the Better Medication Management Scheme, which the government has indicated it will introduce legislation for shortly. The opposition believes that the public really needs to see the full picture and that there needs to be greater consultation with consumers and health professionals, who will be affected by what is coming next. While the opposition certainly supports amending laws to try and stamp out fraud, we do not want this to be done at the expense of access to medicines in emergency situations—people being caught without their Medicare card because they did not know that having it with them was necessary—or by the new system compromising a patient's privacy.
There are a number of people who may not have Medicare cards but who are nevertheless eligible for pharmaceutical benefits—people with disabilities, for example, in the care of a guardian; people who are itinerant; Aboriginal people who do not necessarily carry their Medicare cards all the time; visitors from overseas countries with which Australia has a bilateral agreement; people in emergency situations; and people who just lose their cards. So we need to make sure that, in the implementation of the bill, access to subsidised medicines is not denied to those eligible people. The scheme will need to include a number of these exemptions. I think it would be helpful if these exemptions were made clear before the bill goes through the parliament. 
One of our primary concerns is with privacy and whether the mechanisms used in this bill—that is, for the first time the public exchange of our Medicare numbers—are foreshadowing the government's overall approach to medical records and the development of a unique patient identifier by the Health Insurance Commission. As I indicated last night in my remarks on the Privacy Amendment (Private Sector) Bill 2000, I am a strong supporter of the need for a unique patient identifier and for electronic health records, but not without national health privacy legislation.
We all know—and I am sure this is true for the government as well—that health information cannot be moved online until there is a unique patient identifier developed that can be used to access all the health information held about a particular person, regardless of where that information is held, whether it is in records held by a hospital, medical records held by a doctor or pharmaceutical records held by a pharmacist. I say again that such an identifier represents a very significant threat to a patient's privacy unless strong health privacy legislation is first put in place. Certainly the legislation that has just gone through the House of Representatives is not sufficient in that regard. It will not protect people's health privacy, and I indicate again the opposition's serious concerns with that privacy legislation as far as health is concerned.
So long as that health privacy legislation does not exist, in our view it is certainly premature to be introducing a unique patient identifier. As I said, there is every sign that the Medicare number on people's cards is going to be used in this way with this bill. There are ways to overcome this problem, to make sure that people can have a unique patient identifier that is confidential and that does not appear on the card itself. The last thing we want is someone else picking up our Medicare cards and being able to read the number. At the moment these cards float around but, because we know there is nothing confidential that can be got from them, nobody worries about it too much. Nobody wants that number to be the unique patient identifier. We need to make sure that the identifier is confidential so that nobody can either accidentally or otherwise hack in and read our medical records.
The second privacy concern is how the government will use this information, this information that is going to be collected by pharmacists using the Medicare number, once it is collected. The bill is not clear on this issue. It is certainly the case that there are currently specific Privacy Commissioner guidelines about the use of pharmaceutical data and restrictions on matching that with medical benefits data. That is true. During briefings that we have had with departmental officers they have indicated to us that the data collected, based on our Medicare numbers, will not be matched against existing medical benefits or pharmaceutical benefits data. But there is nothing in the legislation to stop this. If the government could indicate how that is going to be protected, we would appreciate it. We are concerned about the ambiguities that this might create, because it sounds like there are now going to be three data sets collected by the Health Insurance Commission, and it is just not clear what the protections between them will be.
The same concern arises with what we understand is being worked out for the better medication management scheme. What privacy rules will be put in place to protect information that is collected through that scheme, and what data matching arrangements will be allowed? What controls have been put in place to protect an individual's privacy, and what action will the Health Insurance Commission be able to take against any person on the basis of this information alone? There are a number of these issues, particularly relating to privacy, that we certainly think still require some answers. 
If the uncertainty about the operation of the unique patient identifier is allowed to continue, I am concerned that it will harm public confidence in the whole issue of the development of electronic health records. That would be very unfortunate. It would be a major setback, as national standards for electronic health records and decision support systems are essential if we are going to improve the safety and quality of our health services. We are going to need national agreement on what should be included in those electronic records, who should have access to them and what constitutes acceptable security. To reiterate, a separate health privacy regime is urgently needed, not one that is based on voluntary codes, which is all we are going to get from the government's current privacy legislation. I ask the government to clear up a number of these issues. Members of the public that I have talked to about these issues are very concerned because the detailed plans about how electronic health records and unique patient identifiers are going to go forward and what the protections will be are just not clear.
The effectiveness of the measures contained in this bill is also questionable. Under the new scheme, it will not be necessary to have your Medicare card to have a prescription filled. You only have to be able to quote your family's Medicare number and the expiry date of the card, so agents will still be able to go into the chemist shop and collect your prescription if they can quote your Medicare card number. This will leave open most of what we understand to be the currently used methods for ineligible people to obtain a prescription: borrowing a card, using a stolen card or impersonating a friend. We cannot see how this is going to impact on any of the measures that currently exist. It would appear not to be effective even against a person with a stolen prescription impersonating the person to whom the prescription was originally given, because they can simply write down the Medicare number as it appears on the prescription themselves. We are also worried that it will not be effective against doctor shopping if there is no data matching. That really goes back to the question I asked before: what data matching will take place to ensure that doctor shopping is reduced?
So we are concerned that the bill might not make much impact either way—by controlling the use of the PBS by ineligible people or by stopping abuse by doctor shoppers. Whether the Commonwealth will be able to save the amount they anticipate saving is, I have to say, more than a bit doubtful. The saving also looks like it might be offset by the increased costs incurred by implementing these requirements. Already, the Pharmacy Guild has put in a claim for increased payments because of the work involved in checking each prescription. I gather that this was not included in the recently finalised pharmacy agreement. So if, for example, the government pays more than 15c for each transaction for the additional work of checking the Medicare numbers, then the entire savings, even on the government's numbers, could be wiped out. It certainly does not look like a very efficient measure to control fraud and, also because of the cost of all the necessary checks, it looks like the cost might outweigh the savings, if they exist at all.
Pharmacists are also going to have to carry the penalty for any incorrect information being supplied to the Health Insurance Commission, and everyone would understand that they certainly have concerns about that. The government has recently signalled to us that they intend to introduce a whole lot of amendments to this bill. There are six pages of amendments to deal with oversights in the original drafting. I gather it is now common for pharmacists to swipe Medicare cards—although I have never seen my Medicare card swiped—to make an electronic claim on the PBS using the Health Insurance Commission's claims transmission system, and that is provided for under the National Health Act.
These extensive amendments are necessary because the bill unfortunately seems to have been prepared in haste. However, the fact that the government is prepared to listen to representations they have received is a good sign, and we will look at the amendments carefully. Hopefully, they will address some of the concerns that we have raised. It is appropriate that the bill should incorporate provision for electronic transmission of claims. We are not opposed to that because, of course, the underlying objective is to make the system more efficient and accurate without reducing the protection of private information. 
I am disappointed that the government has introduced this legislation separately from the Better Medication Management Scheme, because that scheme promises to develop an electronic system for patient medication records that can be accessed by doctors, pharmacists and patients. That scheme will identify and prevent medication errors at a pharmacy level and it should be introduced in a complementary way to the scheme that we are debating in this bill, which is aiming to reduce inappropriate prescribing as well.
The whole question of inappropriate prescribing has a major impact on the health of Australians, particularly the elderly and those people on multiple medications. And that flows through not only to people who are being cared for in the community but also to people who get a lot of their medications via hospitals. It has been estimated that a substantial number of admissions of the elderly to hospital are the result of problems with medication. A lot more effort needs to be channelled into improving the decision making of prescribers of medications and minimising the extent to which unnecessary or unwise therapies are prescribed in the first place.
Not so long ago I saw an excellent example of this taking place with the South Australian Division of General Practice, who have developed an innovative program to better manage the prescribing of benzodiazepine in the southern region of Adelaide. Unfortunately, that has not been replicated elsewhere. We need to do a whole lot more to improve the quality use of medicines so that adverse results from using medications are reduced.
I have been visiting a lot of hospitals and have met people who are very involved in developing new ways to improve quality and safety in our health system. It is interesting that this issue was the subject of the editorial in today's Australian. The point that is made very powerfully in the editorial in the newspaper today is how slow we have been to address these issues. The editorial says that back in 1995 the federal government was presented with evidence showing that about 18,000 Australians die each year because of medical errors. This is a huge number of people who die because of medical errors that do not need to take place. The editorial correctly says that we have been slow to come up with answers and implement changes.
The government only just last year established the Australian Council for Safety and Quality in Health Care. As the editorial says, it took four years for the government to establish this council—even though the alarm bells about medical mistakes were ringing some time ago. It really is a very tentative step by this government, particularly when you compare it with what is happening in the United States and the United Kingdom where much more dramatic action is being taken to reduce medical errors. The roll-out of information technology throughout our health care system is about making sure that these medical errors are reduced and that we support those at the front line in our health system with evidence so that they can improve the services that are delivered.
I am pleased to see that the Minister for Health and Aged Care has finally announced the National Institute of Clinical Studies. Unfortunately, the institute's establishment is long overdue. It was first announced in May 1999, and the membership of the board of that institute was only announced last Friday. It has taken the government an inordinate amount of time to get this organisation under way. It is a very important organisation, because it is in that place that we can see the very useful collection of meaningful data that can then be provided to those doctors and other health providers out in the community to improve their practice. Unfortunately, this government has been extremely slow at getting around to doing the things that are necessary to improve the quality of health care—whether in hospitals, general practice or any other part of our health system. It is extremely slow, unfortunately, in only recently establishing a committee and now the Institute of Clinical Studies. 
It can only be hoped that we will get some much faster action and some more serious attention to what is an enormously serious problem. Eighteen thousand Australians die each year because of medical errors, and yet it is barely talked about and has been given very little attention to date by this government. I hope that during the debate on this bill we can take it a little bit further, strengthen it and make it more effective to guarantee that, certainly, the subsidised use of pharmaceuticals is only available for those who are eligible and that we are able to significantly limit doctor shopping. Unfortunately, certainly with the way the bill is written at the moment, I do not think it will have much impact.
debate_title: <title>NATIONAL HEALTH AMENDMENT (IMPROVED MONITORING OF ENTITLEMENTS TO PHARMACEUTICAL BENEFITS) BILL 2000</title>

name: Washer, Dr Mal, MP
text:
—The National Health Amendment (Improved Monitoring of Entitlements to Pharmaceutical Benefits) Bill 2000 I am supporting today ensures that only those eligible to obtain prescription medicines through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme do so. The bill will achieve this important aim by gradually introducing a system where a patient's Medicare card will have to be presented when picking up a prescription from the chemist. This will prevent people from using the PBS who are not entitled to, such as people travelling in Australia from overseas. This is another step by the coalition government to help maintain the success and viability of the PBS and to ensure that all Australians continue to have access to subsidised medicines. Importantly, this will be phased in over a period of time, enabling people to get used to the change before its full implementation on 1 July 2001. Patients already know that they have to take their Medicare card when visiting a doctor, and concessional patients already have to produce their health care card when obtaining a prescription from the pharmacy, and so I do not believe that providing their Medicare card will be much more of an impost. Australia has reciprocal arrangements with several countries, including New Zealand and the United Kingdom, and their people will still have access to the PBS—but they must show their passport so that the pharmacist can determine if they are from one of these eligible countries. This will also stop people from overseas obtaining subsidised pharmaceuticals with the intent of taking them home for themselves or other people in their own country.
The savings to the taxpayer as a result of this legislation will amount to more than $40 million over the next four years. The spiralling cost of the PBS is often mentioned in this House, as it is quite significant. This financial year it is expected to reach approximately $3.8 billion. On a global scale, however, we fare quite well, with the cost of the PBS representing just under 12 per cent of the total health budget. This is compared to the 16 per cent in France and nearly 18 per cent in the United Kingdom. The United States only spend 7.8 per cent of their health budget on pharmaceuticals.
The huge cost of the PBS can be attributed to a number of factors. Some of these, such as the advances of modern medicine, cannot be avoided. It is also worth noting that often the cost of subsidising a particular drug can provide cost savings to the community in the long term due to the marked improvement in health of the patient. Take the drug Celebrex, which has just recently been included on the PBS. The cost to patients has been reduced from an average of about $50 to $60 a month to a maximum of $3.30 for health cardholders and $20.60 for general patients. This drug is a major breakthrough in the treatment of arthritis. It is as effective as other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs but it produces significantly fewer adverse side effects. People taking Celebrex will have considerably less gastric irritation and fewer hospital visits due to gastric bleeding and they will use fewer analgesics.
I am concerned, however, that many Australians, in particular seniors, are being overmedicated. Not only is this a strain on the PBS but it also has the potential to be life threatening to the patient. Often people take so many drugs that they would not be able to list them when sitting in front of a doctor. It is difficult to obtain statistics on this but I know from experience how drugs can react dangerously in a person's system if they are already taking another drug that is incompatible. People also hoard medicines. This is costly for both the patient and the PBS, as well as dangerous to the patient and their family, particularly children who risk poisoning themselves. Unfortunately, there are also some people who doctor shop for scripts that they can sell to substance abusers. The drug of choice used to be the self-injecting pethidine, scripts for which people would obtain and then sell. These days people obtain scripts for benzodiazepines, like Serapax and Valium, opiates and the amphetamine based drugs like dexamphetamine and Ritalin. This is one of the important issues that will be addressed when we introduce the better medication management scheme or HealthConnect. That is a separate initiative from the one I am speaking on today but they both relate to the accountability of the distribution of pharmaceuticals in this country. 
I know there are some groups concerned about the privacy issues that are inevitably raised when discussing use of data monitoring and electronic databases. It is not that the information on patients is not already there now. It can be found if someone wants to find it but it is not easy to do so. Part of the push behind HealthConnect is to utilise the technology that is now available to us and enter into electronic medicine. This will allow information on a patient to be easily available to the two most important parties—the patient and the GP. This will also greatly assist hospitals, which will be able to access a patient's history if they come into the hospital unconscious or unable to communicate to the medical staff. Of course, the introduction of a system like HealthConnect needs safeguards to ensure the community will readily accept the new system without privacy concerns. I believe patients' privacy will be enhanced compared to the current paper based system. Access can be restricted to authorised users and patients will be able to find out who has accessed their records.
The issue of a central register or database was raised at a recent hearing of the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs inquiry into substance abuse, which I attended. Users know which doctors to go to around the metropolitan area to obtain scripts for addictive drugs, such as Rohypnol, or `rohies' as they are known on the street. This is another area where we need to crack down on doctor shopping. People desperate for a script can be quite good actors and there is no way for a GP to know what their history is, how many scripts they have obtained that week, or whether they are taking part in a treatment program such as the methadone or naltrexone programs. It would become much more difficult for substance abusers to obtain these prescription drugs if there was some kind of limit—which I would support—that would set off alarm bells if the limit was reached.
People's lives are at stake here and it is important to have the courage to put in place this kind of initiative. We owe it to the parents of the kids who have become mixed up with drugs. They come to these inquiries expressing their anger and amazement at how easy it is to obtain these drugs quite legally through our health system. If we do not accept that we need to accurately record and police doctor shopping, we are, in a sense, accepting a legally sanctioned drug trade. 
Another issue worth noting in the debate on the PBS is the concern that many of the drugs that feature on the top 10 prescribed items in Australia are for ailments that could also be treated by a healthier lifestyle. In 1998, doctors wrote 4.2 million prescriptions for simvastatin, a drug that helps to lower cholesterol. This cost the government $191 million in one year alone, as it was the number one drug on the PBS in terms of expenditure. Australians are fast catching up with people in the United States in adopting a more sedentary lifestyle. Combine that with a high consumption of saturated fats and refined carbohydrates and it does not take a doctor to work out which direction our cholesterol levels are heading in this country—and it is certainly not south. I know there are some people who are genetically predisposed to having high cholesterol levels because their livers produce too much, but many cases are lifestyle induced. 
Another drug in the top 10 prescribed medicines is temazepam, which treats short-term insomnia in adults. Doctors wrote out 3.3 million of these prescriptions in 1998. This is a reflection of the increasingly stressful lifestyles many of us have, and it is of great concern to me that patients will continue to rely on sleeping pills to alleviate a symptom rather than treat the cause. Temazepam is also a favourite drug of choice for substance abusers. 
It is important to ensure money is spent on education campaigns that focus on lifestyle and preventative medicine if we want to maintain a viable PBS. It is also important for the health and wellbeing of our community. On that note, I commend the bill to the House.
debate_title: <title>NATIONAL HEALTH AMENDMENT (IMPROVED MONITORING OF ENTITLEMENTS TO PHARMACEUTICAL BENEFITS) BILL 2000</title>

name: Griffin, Alan, MP
text:
—The National Health Amendment (Improved Monitoring of Entitlements to Pharmaceutical Benefits) Bill 2000 that is before us today has one major aim: to prevent the fraudulent use of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, particularly by tourists, overseas visitors, those with nonresident status and Australian doctor shoppers. The introduction of measures preventing the misuse of Australian taxpayers' money is something that Labor supports unreservedly. Therefore, it is not surprising that we are supporting this bill. 
While the extent and cost of this type of PBS abuse is unknown, the government estimates that the measures it will put in place will save about $16 million per year over the next five years, or 0.55 per cent of last year's total PBS expenditure. In order to achieve these savings, doctors will have to ensure that they record a patient's Medicare number on each PBS prescription. The patient will have to ensure that they are able to present their Medicare number with their prescription to the pharmacist for verification. The pharmacist will have to check the Medicare number against the number on the prescription and record it on their computer database. Finally, the HIC check the number recorded against their own database to make sure they match.
In order that these savings can be realised, the cost of operating the system will have to be less than 15c per prescription. If it costs that or more, the savings generated by the system will be eaten up by administration costs. So the government has to rely on the goodwill of general practitioners and pharmacists in the hope that they will not ask for additional payment for the additional work and time that it will take to operate this system. I would imagine that, for pharmacists, the free provision of this additional service will be doubly inconvenient.
